item.title: The Spring is Just Around the Corner!
item.description:
Welcome! Spring üå∏

The cold wind last week was unbearable, but this week it just feels like spirng has already sprung! Spring is just around the corner in Ecrire06 Naver Blog too! I made some changes in design to welcome upcoming spring.

What do you think about new design? Do you like it or not? I want to hear your opinions in the comments below :)

item.title: Tombow Monotech 500 2.0mm
item.description:
My first Japanese leadholder. Tombow Monotech 2.0mm.

Tombow Monotech 2.0

Tombow, one of the biggest stationery company in Japan, is well known for its quality. ‚ÄúTOMBOW develops products that redefine the traditional uses of stationery and seek to offer the customer excitement and satisfaction.‚Äù according to TOMBOW Homepage. Personally I love Tombow‚Äôs pencils, leadholder and other stationery stuffs. Monotech 2.0mm leadholder is one of them. Let‚Äôs take a look.

Design

Apart from thin and sleeky style other leadholders, Tombow Monotech 2.0mm has a sexy design. Namely, it‚Äôs out-of-box design for leadholder. It has a ‚Äòthick sleeve‚Äô unique clip and hardness indicator. Knurling in grip is also awesome. I think Tombow company loves to make these provacative design.

Components Disassemble

The way Monotech disassembled is different from other leadholders. In general, unscrewing by rotating a ‚Äòclutch‚Äô is a way to disassemble leadholder. I tried that with Monotech, but didn‚Äôt work. To disassemble it, you need to rotate grip part. Clutch has no screw but attached directly to ‚Äòshaft‚Äô.

Two Springs in One Leadholder?

Surprisingly two springs are attached to a single leadholder. Also, unlike other leadholders those two springs are located near the ‚Äògrip‚Äô. (between grip and sleeve) In my point, it seems that it‚Äôs just enough to use a single springs, but Tombow didn‚Äôt. Maybe it‚Äôs easier to design in that wise.

Lead Hardness Indicator

The most impressive point of Tombow Monotech is the design of Lead Hardness Indicator. It‚Äôs really eye-catching. That straightfoward design is quite extraordinary. By turning the Gear-shaped indicator, you can mark the hardness of 2.0mm lead. Tick-Tick sound when turning indicator makes me feel good.

Classfication of Vintage Versions

It seems that the versions of Monotech is divided by the color of grip. When Google ‚ÄòMonotech 2.0mm‚Äô you can find two versions. One grip is silver and the other is black. According to ebay sellers or worthpoint.com, the black version was produced in 1980s, and the siver in 1990s. Check the link below.

  • monotech 500 2.0mm 1990s
  • monotech 2.0mm 1980s
  • monotech 0.5mm 1990s

Clutch holding the lead. ‚ÄòSleeve‚Äô is rectangular-shaped, so turning it (as we use pencils) is impossible. It‚Äôs recommended to use hard leads (H 2H 3H‚Ä¶) which don‚Äôt become bulnt easily.

Original Built-in Lead (10x loupe)

Original built-in lead is ‚ÄòTombow HB 2.0mm lead‚Äô. X1 or Xl is written on the lead, but can‚Äôt find any informations about it. The length is soooooooo long that non of leadholder, except Tombow Monotech, can contain this lead.

This lead is so soft in that it feels like B or 2B. Not recommended for writing. (For drawing it would be okay.) In general, Japanese pencils are usally soft than Europe/American pencils. For example, Faber Castell 9000 HB pencil hardness is similar to Tombow Mono J 2H~3H pencils. I guess it is same for leadholders too.

Metal Stopper attached to original-lead

Metal is attached to original-lead. It‚Äôs called stopper, which prevents the lead fall from leadholder. Many vintage lead has stopper on it. Unfortunately recently-produced-leadholders can‚Äôt use stopper-attached-lead. cf) Recently made Caran d‚ÄôAche Fixpenil can use stopper-attached-lead. It‚Äôs because it has shaft which diameter is quite big.

References

  • Tombow Homepage
  • picclick
  • worthpoint
  • worthpoint 0.5mm
